The Inverse Exponential distribution

Source: R/dist_inverse_exponential.R
dist_inverse_exponential.Rd

dist_inverse_exponential(rate)

Arguments

rate

an alternative way to specify the scale.

See also

actuar::InverseExponential

Examples

dist <- dist_inverse_exponential(rate = 1:5)
dist
#> <distribution[5]>
#> [1] InvExp(1) InvExp(2) InvExp(3) InvExp(4) InvExp(5)

mean(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
variance(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
support(dist)
#> <support_region[5]>
#> [1] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf]
generate(dist, 10)
#> [[1]]
#>  [1]  2.0294141  0.4809964  1.3523181  0.5063017  7.4065709  4.0427111
#>  [7]  0.8635585  0.3206408  0.1260097 13.8113917
#> 
#> [[2]]
#>  [1]  0.7691054  0.5252917  1.4344360  0.7949495 10.8367963  0.3812273
#>  [7]  0.3172083  0.4074894  1.2186644 99.4706378
#> 
#> [[3]]
#>  [1] 0.0936613 0.6758252 2.2141358 0.1399076 3.4150570 0.4814424 0.5994151
#>  [8] 0.3460808 0.4512623 0.3814714
#> 
#> [[4]]
#>  [1] 0.13422166 0.09029014 0.27163385 1.28406727 0.16204041 1.20374314
#>  [7] 0.41026692 0.21295621 0.38949170 0.19968524
#> 
#> [[5]]
#>  [1] 0.3788502 0.1300408 0.3521522 0.4065972 0.1000829 0.2426397 0.7637900
#>  [8] 0.1016347 1.5818703 1.0084550
#> 

density(dist, 2)
#> [1] 0.15163266 0.09735010 0.07054014 0.05515606 0.04524187
density(dist, 2, log = TRUE)
#> [1] -1.886294 -2.329442 -2.651573 -2.897589 -3.095732

cdf(dist, 4)
#> [1] 0.7788008 0.8824969 0.9200444 0.9394131 0.9512294

quantile(dist, 0.7)
#> [1] 2.8036733 1.4018366 0.9345578 0.7009183 0.5607347
